Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: what is the difference between `baton` and `batontxid`?

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I see `baton` is an address

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: and `batontxid` is a typical txid has

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: hash

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I guess I should ask, what is the baton address used for?

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: do all batontxids take place in the baton address?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the batontxid is the baton utxo sent to the baton address

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: this is changing my understanding

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I think part of the difficulty in understanding this is that I'm still confused about how cc addresses work...

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: when a publisher does `oraclesregister`, do they get both a `baton` and `batontxid`?

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I'm looking through the method, but it's a long complicated hex

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: and I don't see any mention of baton in `oraclesregister`

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: baton address is just the address of the publisher

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: normal address

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: Getscriptaddress(batonaddr,regtx.vout[1].scriptPubKey);

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh, sorry it is a CC address

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which is a CC script derived from the publishers pubkey, so it has the publishers pubkey and the oracles eval code

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is put into crypto-conditions serialization

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then it is hashed and that is the OP_CHECKCRYPTOCONDITIONS script

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I then use the normal method of calculating bitcoin addresses by hashing the CC vout scriptPubkey, adding KMD prefix and base58 encoding it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if anything about the CC vout is changed, the address changes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so a different pubkey changes the CC address

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a different evalcode, changes the CC address

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a different cryptocondition (1of2, 2of2, etc) will change the CC address

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the CC address is just the base58 encoding of the serialized cryptocondition hash

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so each pubkey gets one CC address per different CC

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
interesting. I think i follow that. Will save it.

going to write instructions and more details about cc addresses soon

Content:
Also, this question from earlier:

curious, in oraclesregister, why do we have the user indicate the desired publisher by using batonutxo, and not baton? 

as the baton address doesn't change, but the batonutxo does,  why do we use batonutxo?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think you are confused about batons

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oraclesregister is done only by the publisher

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: he creates the first baton

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: blockchains dont have addresses in them, just pubkeys or hashes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: by specifying a specific baton utxo, you specify the baton address and further, the specific tx in the linked list

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you lock your funds in to a special contract, then it can be claimed by heirs if you dont use the funds for a year

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: this is one of the problems that if solved, could be a big deal.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seems rather a trivial thing to do...

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: Thats a good way to do it. If you don't move the funds within a year, the keys you gave to your beneficiary would have access to the funds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: basically you want a DMS

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so there is the big stash of funds locked in the inheritance address, a set of smaller amount addresses are referenced, if all of them are idle for the specified amount of time, the heir can spend the big stash

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the owner is free to withdraw funds from the big stash at any time

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: so how reliable would the date keeping be? would it be referenced to a particular block height?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it would be X amount of time/blocks from the last time any of the referenced addresses sent any funds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: simpler to make it blocks (minutes)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: simplest case is to refer to the big stash address itself. then if you stop using it, it can be claimed

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: is cc modular enough to do this with other coins or would it be exclusive to kmd?

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: I guess all you need is to display a message with the key

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: any CC activated chain can be used

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if tokens are supported, then tokenized versions of other coins can also be done,but that makes it more complicated to do

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: It would be pretty trick to hack some thing like a ledger hardware wallet to do it for you.

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: your heirs plug it in, open the app, "funds not accessible"... wait a year. "I'm dead, here's your inheritance"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ledger wouldnt support it

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: ledger the company? or the hardware itself is not capable of referencing the contract?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ledger only does normal taddr tx, not CC

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: so is it just a matter of writing the firmware to make cc work with an appropriate chipset?

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: idk, I'm way out of my depth here. just spitballing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: considering how much work it was to get rewards claiming working, getting CC support is like 1000x the effort

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe by the year 2500

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: Yeah I've been following that. lukechilds made the magic happen.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442

Author: Mihailo#5902

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: How would you introduce the channels smart contract?

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: What's it generally about, and how does it work?

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I'll take your description and turn this into a paragraph or three, depending on how complex.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Channels CC is a mechanism to make instant payments between two points without a need to wait for transactions to get in the chain and be confirmed. This possible because the funds are locked in a special CC address that could be spent only by owners of private keys for those two pubkeys that are used in creating channel and then funds are released with each payment by the sender to receiver. After that tx with locking funds is protected with dPoW (notarized)  the receiving party can be sure it will receive funds at the moment the payment tx gets in the mempool.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: So channels creates instant payments -- verified as soon as they are in the mempool.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: that's a useful feature!

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Correct

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Very

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Can we combine this with other cc's?

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Well, there is idea to combine it with other CCs to be able to instant pay tokens or tokenized deposit from gateway and etc.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: It is not so simple to combine multiple CCs
